skill.name: cursor
skill.description: Control Cursor AI code editor via CLI. Open files, folders, diffs, and manage extensions.
skill.summary: Control Cursor AI code editor via CLI. Open files, folders, diffs, and manage extensions.
skill.author: Dicklesworthstone

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing only markdown content about Cursor CLI usage. No executable code, no network calls, no file system access, no environment variable access. The skill provides prompts and documentation only.

content.user_title: Control Cursor editor from command line
content.value_statement: Managing Cursor editor through GUI is slow for developers who prefer terminal workflows. This skill provides commands to open files, folders, diffs, and manage extensions directly from CLI.
actual_capabilities: Open files and folders in Cursor editor
Open files at specific lines and columns
Configure wait mode for script integration
Set up Cursor as git editor
limitations: Requires Cursor editor to be installed on the system
CLI must be available at standard path (/usr/local/bin/cursor)
Some features like remote development require GUI interaction
Portable mode paths must be manually configured

use_cases.title: Open code from terminal
use_cases.description: Quickly open projects and files in Cursor without leaving your terminal workflow

use_cases.title: Use as git editor
use_cases.description: Configure Cursor as your git commit editor for better commit message writing

use_cases.title: Manage extensions via CLI
use_cases.description: Install and manage Cursor extensions programmatically in scripts

prompt_templates.title: Open current directory
prompt_templates.prompt: Open the current directory in Cursor editor using the cursor CLI

prompt_templates.title: Open file at line
prompt_templates.prompt: Open /path/to/file.ts at line 42 in Cursor editor

prompt_templates.title: Compare two files
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare file1.ts and file2.ts using Cursor diff mode

prompt_templates.title: Install extension
prompt_templates.prompt: Install the VSCode extension with ID 'ms-python.python' using Cursor CLI

output_examples.input: Open the current directory in Cursor editor
output: Cursor opens displaying your current project
All files are visible in the sidebar

best_practices: Use wait mode (-w flag) when calling cursor from scripts to ensure files are saved before continuing
Configure cursor as git editor with 'git config --global core.editor "cursor --wait"'
Use --user-data-dir for portable setups or when managing multiple Cursor profiles
anti_patterns: Calling cursor without verifying the file path exists, which may cause errors
Using diff mode without specifying two valid file paths
Skipping the --wait flag when using cursor in automated scripts

faq.question: Does this skill work on Windows?
faq.answer: Cursor is available on Windows, macOS, and Linux. The CLI path may vary by operating system.

faq.question: What versions of Cursor are supported?
faq.answer: This skill works with recent versions of Cursor that include the full CLI functionality.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with other tools?
faq.answer: Yes, cursor CLI integrates with git, shell scripts, and any tool that can spawn processes.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: This skill only provides documentation. The Cursor editor handles your data according to its own privacy settings.

faq.question: What if cursor command is not found?
faq.answer: Ensure Cursor is installed and the CLI is added to your system PATH. Reinstall Cursor if needed.

faq.question: How is this different from VS Code CLI?
faq.answer: Cursor is a fork of VS Code with AI features. Its CLI shares many commands but is specific to Cursor.
